sentences.sentence: It was half past five before Holmes returned.
He was bright, eager, and in excellent spirits—a mood( 情绪 ) which in his case alternated( 交替 ) with fits of the blackest depression( 沮丧 ).
“There is no great mystery( 谜 ) in this matter,” he said, taking the cup of tea which I had poured out for him. “The facts appear to admit of( 容许有 ) only one explanation.”
“What! You have solved it already?”
“Well, that would be too much to say. I have discovered a suggestive fact, that is all.
It is, however, very suggestive. The details( 详细情况 ) are still to be added.
I have just found, on consulting the back files of the Times, that Major Sholto, of Upper Norwood, late of the 34th Bombay Infantry( 步兵部队 ), died upon the 28th of April, 1882.”
“I may be very stupid, Holmes, but I don’t see what this suggests.”
“No? You surprise me. Look at it in this way, then.
Captain Morstan disappears. The only person in London whom he could have visited is Major Sholto.
Major Sholto denies( 否认 ) having heard that he was in London. Four years later Sholto dies.
Within a week of his death Captain Morstan’s daughter receives a valuable present, which is repeated from year to year, and now finally, this letter which describes her as a wronged woman.
What wrong can it refer to( 指代 ) except this deprivation( 丧失 ) of her father?
And why should the presents begin immediately after Sholto’s death, unless because Sholto’s heir( 继承人 ) knows something of the mystery( 神秘事件 ) and desires to make compensation( 补偿 )?
Have you any alternative theory which will meet the facts?”
“But what a strange compensation! Why, too, should he write a letter now, rather than six years ago?
Again, the letter speaks of giving her justice. What justice can she have? It is too much to suppose that her father is still alive.”
“There are difficulties,” said Sherlock Holmes, thoughtfully, “but our expedition( 历险 ) of tonight will solve them all.
Ah, here is a four-wheeler, and Miss Morstan is inside. Are you ready? Then we had better go down, for it is a little past the hour.”
I picked up my hat and my heaviest stick, but I observed that Holmes took his gun from his drawer and slipped it into his pocket.
It was clear that he thought that our night’s work might be a serious one.
Miss Morstan was wrapped( 包裹 ) in a dark cloak( 斗篷 ), and her sensitive face was calm, but pale.
She must have felt some uneasiness at the strange enterprise upon which we were setting out,
yet her self-control was perfect, and she readily answered the few additional questions which Sherlock Holmes put to her.
“Major Sholto was a very special friend of papa’s,” she said. “Papa talked a lot about the major in his letters.
The major and papa were in command of( 指挥 ) the troops at the Andaman Islands, so they were together a good deal.
By the way, a curious paper was found in papa’s desk which no one could understand.
I don’t suppose it is important, but I thought you might want to see it, so I brought it with me. Here it is.”
Holmes unfolded the paper carefully and smoothed it out upon his knee.
He then very methodically examined it all over with his magnifying glass( 放大镜 ).
“It is paper of native Indian manufacture( 制造 ),” he remarked. “It has at some time been pinned to a board.
The diagram upon it appears to be a map of part of a large building with many halls, corridors( 走廊 ), and passages.
At one point is a small cross done in red ink, and above it is ‘3.37 from left’ in faded pencil-writing.
In the left-hand corner is a curious shape like four crosses in a line with their arms touching.
Beside it is written, in very rough and coarse( 粗的 ) characters, ‘The sign of the four—Jonathan Small, Mahomet Singh, Abdullah Khan, Dost Akbar.’
No, I confess( 坦白 ) that I do not see how this bears upon( 与事件有关系 ) the matter. Yet it is evidently a document of importance.
It has been kept carefully in a pocket-book( 口袋钱夹 ); for the one side is as clean as the other.”
“It was in his pocketbook that we found it.”
“Keep it carefully, then, Miss Morstan, for it may prove useful to us.
I begin to suspect( 怀疑 ) that this matter may turn out to be much deeper and more subtle( 微妙的 ) than I at first supposed. I must reconsider my ideas.”
He leaned( 倾斜 ) back in the cab, and I could see by his wrinkled forehead and his vacant eyes that he was thinking intently.

Miss Morstan and I chatted in an undertone about our present expedition( 历险 ) and its possible result, but our companion maintained( 保持 ) his impenetrable( 难接近的 ) reserve until the end of our journey.
It was a September evening, and not yet seven o’clock, but the day had been a dreary( 阴沉的 ) one, and a dense( 浓密的 ) drizzly( 下毛毛雨的 ) fog lay low upon the great city.
Down the Strand the lamps were but misty patches of blurred( 模糊的 ) light which threw a feeble( 微弱的 ) circular glimmer( 微光 ) upon the wet pavement( 路面 ).
There was, to my mind, something ghost( 鬼魂 )-like in the endless procession of faces which flitted across these narrow patches of light—sad faces and glad, desperate and merry.
Like all humans, they flitted from the darkness into the light, and so back into the darkness once more.
I am not subject to( 受...支配 ) impressions, but the dull, heavy evening, with the strange business upon which we were engaged( 参与 ), combined to make me nervous and depressed( 情绪低落的 ).
I could see from Miss Morstan’s manner that she was suffering from( 受折磨 ) the same feeling.
Holmes alone was unaffected.
He held his open notebook upon his knee, and from time to time he noted down figures and ideas in it.
At the Lyceum Theater the crowds were already thick at the side-entrances.
In front a continuous stream of cabs were hurrying up, discharging( 放出 ) their cargoes( 货物（这里指乘客） ) of men in suits and women in their best shawls and necklaces.
We had hardly reached the third pillar( 柱子 ), which was our meeting point, before a small, dark man dressed like a cab-driver came up to us.
“Are you the friends who come with Miss Morstan?” he asked.
“I am Miss Morstan, and these two gentlemen are my friends,” said she.
He looked at us with penetrating( 犀利的 ) and questioning eyes.
“You will excuse me, miss,” he said with a certain persistent( 执着的 ) manner, “but I was to ask you to give me your word that neither of your companions is a policeman.”
“I give you my word( 我向你保证 ) on that,” she answered.
He gave a loud whistle and a young boy led across a four-wheeler and opened the door.

question.cn: Holmes所发现的对案件侦破极具启发性的一件事是什么？
question.en: What was the suggestive fact that Holmes discovered?

options.cn: Sholto少校并不知道Morstan上尉身在伦敦。
options.en: Major Sholto didn’t know that Captain Morstan was in London.

options.cn: Sholto少校去世正是在Miss Morstan第一次收到珍珠的前一周。
options.en: Major Sholto died just a week before Miss Morstan received the first pearl.

options.cn: Sholto少校就是询问Miss Morstan地址的那个人。
options.en: Major Sholto was the person who had asked for Miss Morstan’s address.

analysis: 文中Holmes提到自己发现：“Major Sholto. . . died upon the 28th of April, 1882.”当Watson不明白这件事跟案件有何相关时他进一步解释道：“Four years later Sholto dies. Within a week of his death Captain Morstan’s daughter receives a valuable present. . . ”因此答案选B。

question.cn: 根据Holmes的观点，Miss Morstan为什么会开始收到礼物？
question.en: According to Holmes’ theory, why did Miss Morstan begin to receive presents?

options.cn: 因为Sholto的继承人想要作出补偿。
options.en: Because Sholto’s heir wanted to make compensation.

options.cn: 因为她的父亲仍然活着。
options.en: Because her father was still alive.

options.cn: 因为她被错当成了别人。
options.en: Because she was mistaken for someone else.

analysis: 文中Holmes说道：“And why should the presents begin immediately after Sholto’s death, unless because Sholto’s heir knows something of the mystery and desires to make compensation? Have you any alternative theory which will meet the facts?”因此答案选A。

question.cn: Holmes对Miss Morstan带来的那张奇怪的图纸有何看法？
question.en: What did Holmes think of the curious paper Miss Morstan brought?

options.en: It was nearly of no use.
It might prove useful to them.

analysis: 文中提到：“It has been kept carefully in a pocket-book; for the one side is as clean as the other.”可知C项错误；又有Holmes说道：“Keep it carefully, then, Miss Morstan, for it may prove useful to us.”因此答案选B。

question.en: How was the weather that night?

options.en: It was windy and extremely cold.

options.cn: 那是一个阴沉的下着毛毛雨的大雾天。
options.en: It was a dreary day with a dense drizzly fog.

analysis: 文中提到：“It was a September evening, and not yet seven o’clock, but the day had been a dreary one, and a dense drizzly fog lay low upon the great city. ”因此答案选C。

question.cn: 在柱子处有人出现了吗？
question.en: Did anyone show up at the pillar?

options.cn: 有，一个小个子、深色皮肤的人。

analysis: 今天内容的结尾处提到：“We had hardly reached the third pillar, which was our meeting point, before a small, dark man dressed like a cab-driver came up to us.”因此答案选A。
